grammarPoints.usage: Use '在' (zài) before verbs to indicate ongoing action
Use '着' (zhe) after verbs to indicate continuous state
Use '过' (guo) after verbs to indicate past experience
Use '没(有)' before verb + '过' to negate experience
Use 'A + 比 + B + Adjective' for comparisons
Use 'A + 跟 + B + 一样 (+ Adj)' for similarity
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I am as tall as you

grammarPoints.usage: Use '有点儿' (yǒudiǎnr) before adjectives, often negative
Use '快...了' to express something is about to happen
Use '要...了' for imminent future actions
Use '应该' (yīnggāi) to express obligation or likelihood
Use '得' (děi) to express necessity
Use '得' (de) to connect verbs with result/degree complements
Use '起来' after verbs to indicate beginning of action
Use '下去' after verbs to indicate continuation
Use '一边...一边...' for simultaneous actions
Use '先...然后...' to sequence actions
Use '又...又...' to express two qualities
Use '一...就...' for immediately sequential actions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: As soon as I get home, I sleep

grammarPoints.usage: Use '除了...以外' to express exception or addition

grammarPoints.meaning: for the purpose of/in order to
grammarPoints.usage: Use '为了' (wèile) to express purpose
Use '因为...所以...' for cause and effect
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Because it's raining, so we won't go

grammarPoints.usage: Use '虽然...但是...' for concession
Use '如果...就...' for conditional statements
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: If it rains, then won't go

grammarPoints.usage: Use '只' (zhǐ) before verbs for 'only'
Use '就' (jiù) for emphasis on time or quantity
Use '才' (cái) for 'only' or 'not until' (later than expected)
Use '已经' (yǐjīng) with '了' for completed actions
Use '还没' (hái méi) to express 'not yet'
Use '刚' (gāng) for actions just completed
Use '离' (lí) with distance adjectives
Use '往' (wǎng) to indicate direction
Use '对' (duì) before person in certain expressions
Use '被' (bèi) for passive voice
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I was criticized by the teacher

grammarPoints.usage: Use '把' (bǎ) to move object before verb
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I put the book on the table

grammarPoints.usage: Use '最' (zuì) before adjectives for superlative
Use '更' (gèng) for 'even more'
Use '有的...有的...' to describe different groups
grammarPoints.example: 有的人喜欢，有的人不喜欢
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Some people like it, some don't

grammarPoints.usage: Use '别' (bié) for negative commands
Use '让' (ràng) for causative constructions
Use '帮' (bāng) for helping constructions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Help me hold this for a moment

grammarPoints.usage: Use '完' after verbs to indicate completion
Use '到' after verbs to indicate reaching a goal
Use '见' after perception verbs
Use '好' after verbs to indicate proper completion
Use '上' after verbs for successful completion or upward direction
Use '下' after verbs for fitting or downward direction
Use '出来' for emerging or figuring out
Use '进去' for entering
Use '回来' for returning
Use '过来' for approaching
Use '过去' for going away
Use '不是...而是...' for correction
Use '不但...而且...' for addition
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Not only smart, but also hardworking

grammarPoints.usage: Use '越来越' for progressive change
Use '越...越...' for correlative progression
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The more I study, the more interesting it becomes

grammarPoints.usage: Use '连...都/也...' for emphasis
Use '不仅...也...' for addition (synonym of 不但...而且)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Not only good-looking, but also cheap

grammarPoints.usage: Use '就是...也...' for concession
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Even if it rains, I'll still go

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不管...都...' for unconditional statements
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: No matter what, I'll still go

grammarPoints.usage: Use '只要...就...' for sufficient conditions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: As long as you work hard, you'll succeed

grammarPoints.usage: Use '只有...才...' for necessary conditions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Only if you work hard, can you succeed

grammarPoints.usage: Use '无论...都...' for unconditional statements (formal)
Use '要是...就...' for conditional (colloquial)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: If it rains, then won't go

grammarPoints.usage: Use '与其...不如...' for preference
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Rather than stay home, better to go out

grammarPoints.usage: Use '宁可...也不...' for strong preference
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Would rather walk than take a car

grammarPoints.usage: Use '既然...就...' for logical consequence
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Since you came, have a good time

grammarPoints.usage: Use '既...又...' for dual qualities (formal)
Use '以为' for mistaken beliefs
Use '觉得' for opinions or feelings
Use '认为' for considered opinions

grammarPoints.meaning: to hear that/it is said that
grammarPoints.usage: Use '听说' for hearsay
Use '据说' for reported information
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: It is said that it will rain tomorrow

grammarPoints.usage: Use '好像' for appearance or similarity
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: It seems like it's going to rain

grammarPoints.usage: Use '看起来' for visual appearance
Use '看上去' similar to '看起来'
Use '原来' for discoveries or past states
Use '到底' in questions for emphasis
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Are you going or not (tell me clearly)?

grammarPoints.usage: Use '究竟' for emphasis in questions (formal)
